content.title: Treibhausgasemissionen nach Wirtschaftsakteur – Haushalte verantwortlich für mehr als 80 Prozent der Zunahme der Treibhausgasemissionen zwischen 1990 und 2005
content.lead: (BFS) - Zwischen 1990 und 2005 sind die Treibhausgasemissionen der Schweiz um 3,6 Prozent von 61 auf 63,2 Millionen Tonnen CO2-Äquivalente gestiegen. Diese Zunahme geht zu mehr als 80 Prozent auf das Konto der Haushalte, deren Verkehrsemissionen 1,8 Millionen Tonnen (+20%) höher waren als 15 Jahre zuvor. Für die restlichen 0,4 Millionen Tonnen ist die Wirtschaft verantwortlich, deren Emissionen in diesem Zeitraum um 1 Prozent angestiegen sind. Diese Ergebnisse stammen aus einer Zusammenstellung der Treibhausgasemissionen nach Wirtschaftsakteuren, die das Bundesamt für Statistik (BFS) nach den Prinzipien der Volkswirtschaftlichen Gesamtrechung erstellt hat.

content.title: Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre par acteur économique – Les ménages responsables de plus de 80% de la hausse des émissions de gaz à effet de serre entre 1990 et 2005
content.lead: (OFS) - Entre 1990 et 2005, les émissions de gaz à effet de serre de la Suisse ont augmenté de 3,6%, passant de 61 à 63,2 millions de tonnes d'équivalent CO2. Cet accroissement est dû à plus de 80% aux ménages, dont les émissions des transports ont progressé de plus de 1,8 million de tonnes (+20%) en quinze ans. Le solde d'environ 0,4 million de tonnes est de la responsabilité de l'économie, dont les émissions ont augmenté de 1% durant cette période. Ces résultats proviennent d'une comptabilisation par l'Office fédéral de la statistique (OFS) des émissions de gaz à effet de serre par acteur économique et selon les principes des Comptes nationaux.

content.title: Le emissioni di gas serra per attore economico – Economie domestiche all'origine di oltre l'80 per cento dell'incremento di emissioni di gas serra tra il 1990 e il 2005
content.lead: (UST) - Tra il 1990 e il 2005, le emissioni di gas serra della Svizzera sono aumentate del 3,6 per cento, passando da 61 a 63,2 milioni di tonnellate di equivalenti CO2. Più dell'80 per cento di questa crescita è da ricondurre alle economie domestiche, le cui emissioni da trasporto sono lievitate di 1,8 milioni di tonnellate (+20%) nell'arco di 15 anni. La parte rimanente, pari a circa 0,4 milioni di tonnellate, è invece dovuta all'economia, le cui emissioni sono aumentate dell'1 per cento nello stesso periodo. Questi sono i risultati di un'analisi effettuata dall'Ufficio federale di statistica (UST) volta a quantificare le emissioni di gas serra per attore economico sulla base dei principi dei conti economici nazionali.

content.title: Greenhouse gas emissions by economic player – Households responsible for more than 80% of increase in greenhouse gas emissions between 1990 and 2005
content.lead: (FSO) - Between 1990 and 2005, greenhouse gas emissions in Switzerland increased by 3.6%, rising from 61 to 63.2 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent. More than 80% of this growth was caused by households, whose transport emissions increased by more than 1.8 million tonnes (+20%) in fifteen years. The approximately 0.4 million tonnes remaining can be accounted for by the economy, whose emissions rose by 1% during this period. These results come from the Federal Statistical Office's (FSO) accounting of greenhouse gas emissions by economic player, based on national accounting principles. Due to the consistency with the National Accounts, these results differ from those of the Swiss greenhouse gas inventory according to the Kyoto Protocol. In fact, all emissions generated by economic activities are accounted for, including CO2 emissions from biomass used as fuel and from air traffic. In 2005, households and the economy generated 39% and 61%, respectively, of greenhouse gas emissions in Switzerland. Heating accounted for 56% of household emissions, transport for 44%. As far as the economy is concerned, emissions were generated mainly by the manufacturing industry (29%), transport (15%), agriculture (15%) and waste management (15%).
